The Imanta neighborhood was built during Soviet times with row after row of concrete apartment blocks.
Here, I run into Erik Darznieks, a driver who's out for a walk with his wife.
He thinks the law is really about October's Parliamentary election.
(Through interpreter) It's pure politics.
If there weren't such bans like the language law, there would be a lot fewer problems in our society.
Darznieks is ethnic Latvian but says he feels more comfortable speaking Russian.
He says language isn't an issue in daily life.
Darznieks laughs when I mention the opponents of the law are accused of being puppets of the Russian president.
(LAUGHTER)
(Foreign language spoken).
Darznieks says he's never considered himself one of Vladimir Putin's helpers.
But Russia's annexation of Crimea four years ago is still on the minds of many Latvians.
Putin justified his military intervention in Ukraine by claiming to defend the rights of Russian speakers there.
Elizabete Krivcova says a similar scenario could happen in Latvia.
If our politician will increase this ethnic tension, then, on one point, it would be possible.
Krivcova is an ethnic Russian activist who is suing the Latvian government over the language law.
The Latvian security services suspect her of working for the Kremlin.
She says she's acting on her own convictions.
I hope we will find a good way in our state without violence, actually, and without need to ask help to any foreign country.
Latvia's sovereignty is supported by its membership in NATO and the European Union.
Karlis Sadurskis, the education minister, says the new law is intended to defuse ethnic tension.
If we are not learning together, we are not able normally to live together.
And, therefore, this is just breaking ice between two communities in Latvia.
He says the new law will help integrate Russian speakers into Latvian society.
Lucian Kim, NPR News, Riga, Latvia.
Congressman Ryan, to the extent he's known at all, has earned notoriety as the author of a controversial budget plan that would dramatically make over the nation's two largest health programs.
And as NPR's Julie Rovner reports, his addition to the ticket will present the public with a dramatic choice about the roll the government should play in health care.
One thing Paul Ryan never does is apologize for thinking big.
Here he is on ABC's ""This Week"" back in February.
We also think we have a moral obligation to try and fix this country's big problems before they get out of our control.
Ryan is referring, among other things, to the budget plan he wrote and helped muscle through the House, twice.
It would cut taxes, create private accounts for Social Security and, perhaps most notably, make major changes to the Medicare and Medicaid health programs.
The Medicare changes in particular are dramatic.
Starting a decade from now, seniors would get a set amount of money rather than automatic coverage.
They could use that to choose from a range of health plans.
Here's how Ryan explained it at a news conference with Democratic Senator Ron Wyden last December.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED NEWS CONFERENCE)
But the amount of money the senior gets wouldn't necessarily go up as fast as medical costs.
Ryan and those who support his idea say that choice and competition would maintain the benefits.
Others, including President Obama, aren't so sure.
Here's the president from a speech last spring, in which he blasted Ryan's budget plan.
It says instead of guaranteed health care, you will get a voucher.
And if that voucher isn't worth enough to buy the insurance that's available in the open marketplace, well, tough luck, you're on your own.
On Medicaid, Ryan's proposal would give states far more flexibility to decide how and who to cover, but also less money to do it with.
Here's how he explained in on the PBS ""NewsHour.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""NEWSHOUR"")

Fisher says it works on a wide range of misfolded proteins, but the first studies of its effectiveness in people will involve patients with Alzheimer's.
He says the goal is to show that the treatment reduces those clumps of tau and beta-amyloid protein.
Once we show that, we can go into, for example, Parkinson's disease.
And attack a different misfolded protein.
Jon Hamilton, NPR News.
The story you're about to hear is, at its heart, a love story between two artists and a whole lot of dogs.
It's also the story of what it means to follow a dream and the difficulties that can bring.
And it's a story of Vermont artists Stephen and Gwen Huneck and their life's work, a place called Dog Mountain.
People will be driving their dogs up.
They will get to the bottom of the hill, and the dogs will go ballistic.
(SOUNDBITE OF DOG BARKING)
And as soon as the doors open, they're out jumping into the pond, and they're having a ball.
(SOUNDBITE OF WATER SPLASHING)
My name is Jon Ide - Gwen's older brother.
When somebody hears about Dog Mountain, it sounds, you know, maybe a little bit goofy, but it's anything but.
There are no fences, and dogs are welcome, or as Gwen liked to say, they're cherished.
All right, folks, we're going to get on with the dog party contest.
They have these dog parties where several hundred people will come with their dogs and play.

UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN #2: All right.
UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN #1: Do we have singer in the crowd?
Otis, what you think, buddy?
You want to sing?
(SOUNDBITE OF HARMONICA MUSIC AND DOG HOWLING)
I'm from Don Cherry.
We're from Littleton, N.H., and that's Otis.
He is in Akita and Chow mix and whatever else he could possibly be.
(SOUNDBITE OF DOG HOWLING)
UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN #1: That is fabulous, Otis.
(APPLAUSE)
The Dog Mountain story began in the 1970s, when Stephen Huneck met Gwen Ide in art school.
Independent producer Dan Collison takes over from here.
Stephen and Gwen Huneck were married for 35 years.
They never had kids, but they always had dogs.
